turtlesData.name: Leatherback Sea Turtle
turtlesData.interesting_fact: Apart from being the largest of the sea turtle species, leatherback turtles are unique in a variety of ways. They have a soft, oily, leather-like shell that is highly pliable.

additional_info.distribution: Nearly all tropical and subtropical waters

turtlesData.name: Green Sea Turtle
turtlesData.interesting_fact: Green turtles are the only turtle species that feed primarily on plant material. They are known to scavenge on sponges, invertebrates, and fish remnants.

additional_info.size: Up to 4 feet in length and up to 500 lbs
additional_info.distribution: Primarily Pacific and Atlantic Oceans, also Indian Ocean

turtlesData.name: Hawksbill Sea Turtle
turtlesData.interesting_fact: Hawksbill turtles have a highly specialized diet, feeding almost entirely on sea sponges by using their bird-like beak to reach through cracks and crevices.

additional_info.size: Up to 3 feet in length and up to 200 lbs
additional_info.distribution: Tropical and some subtropical regions in the Atlantic, Pacific Ocean, and Indian Oceans

turtlesData.name: Loggerhead Sea Turtle
turtlesData.interesting_fact: Loggerhead turtles get their name from their large head and strong jaws. Feeding on hard-shelled prey such as crabs, conchs, and whelks, adult loggerheads are carnivorous.

additional_info.nesting_sites: Largest nesting occurs on Masirah Island off the coast of Oman

turtlesData.name: Olive Ridley Sea Turtle
turtlesData.interesting_fact: Olive ridley turtles have a fascinating nesting behavior known as arribadas, where thousands of nesting turtles gather on a single shoreline during nesting season.

additional_info.distribution: Primarily warm waters of the Indo-Pacific, with small populations in the Atlantic Ocean
additional_info.feeding_habit: Omnivorous, feeding on a variety of sea life

turtlesData.name: Kemp’s Ridley Sea Turtle
turtlesData.interesting_fact: Kemp’s ridley turtles are the rarest and smallest sea turtle species. They reach maturity within 10 – 15 years and can successfully mate within that time frame.

additional_info.distribution: Primarily Gulf of Mexico and along the Atlantic coast
additional_info.nesting_behavior: Form large nesting groups during the day

turtlesData.name: Flatback Sea Turtle
turtlesData.interesting_fact: Flatbacks have a flat carapace (the area at the top of the shell), which is different from the rounded shell of other turtles. They are found breeding and nesting only on the coast of Australia.
